description: Variation of condition 2 (Approved Plans) of planning application reference: 18/12205/FUL for the 'Erection of single storey side and rear extension, first floor side extension, hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions to facilitate conversion of existing dwellinghouse to create 1 x 2 bed and 1 x 3 bed self-contained unit to include increased depth of rear extension, additional extension to the side of the dwelling, alterations to approved roof configuration and removal of chimney stack.
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(l) A scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and  construction works (Major Applications).Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because:[amend as appropriate]- the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase, or- the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset;- to safeguard residential amenity;- to ensure the development would have a satisfactory appearance.

The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from 06 February 2019 the date of the originally approved application 18/12205/FUL that is the subject of this application for variation. Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990. (As amended)

The development shall conform in all material aspects with the plans and detail    shown in the application, as listed below, unless variations are agreed by the Local Planning Authority in order to discharge other conditions as attached to this decision.Reason: For the avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the LocalPlanning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of the development, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the councilconfirming that the development hereby approved has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions ( ENE1 ), internal water usage ( WAT1 ) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l / p / day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1(Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
J3 - Warning of Release of Carbon Monoxide
E4 - Acoustic Conditions in Schools
F1 - Means of Ventilation

Application SiteThe site comprises a flat/semi-detached/linked/detached dwelling.ProposalConsultationAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- (Add more bullet points in here if necessary)DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling. The site does not fall within a conservation area but does adjoin the Claremont Road Conservation area.ProposalErection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with installation of 4no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversionConsultationEighty neighbouring properties have been notified and one objection has been raised with regards to considerate parking in the neighbouring car park. This is not a material consideration but an informative can be included should permission be granted reminding the applicant of the importance of considerate parking.Surbiton Neighbourhood Conservation Area Advisory Committee -  Objection unless revised - the design is not of a high enough standard to be acceptable within the CA and therefore in its present form, the proposals would result in harm to the CA. Thelarger rear dormer should be reduced in size and the upper part should sit below the ridgeline. As designed at present, large dormers such as the one proposed appear excessively large sit poorly within the roofscape and are therefore not appropriate in the CA. Any roof lights should be kept to a minimum and employ flush/conservation grade profiles.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on the adjoining Conservation Area.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them. As noted above, the site although not in the Conservation area, does adjoin it. Officers would therefore be required to assess the development as it would effect the land and buildings within it.Officer Comment: The proposed rear dormer is not in compliance with Policy 39 of residential design guide SPD as it has not been set down from the ridge of the existing roof. It is therefore not considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. The proposed hip to gable roof extension would not complement the character of the original or neighbouring dwellings. It would appear contrived and discordant in appearance from the street and to the original property by way of its overall design.  It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.Officers consider that the proposal would amount to less than substantial harm to the conservation area and it is therefore necessary to weigh this against any public benefits of the proposal. The applicant has not advanced any arguments as to the public benefits of the proposal, nor is it apparent to Officers that there would be any. The proposed development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the conservation area and there would be no public benefits to outweigh the identified harm, thereby conflicting with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is not considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a two-storey, semi-detached dwelling located on the south side of Somerset Close, which is a well-established residential area. The property is set in from the side boundary with no. 41 Somerset Close by a driveway that leads to a parking space at the rear of the property. The rear garden of the property has a depth of approximately 18m, beyond which are the rear gardens of properties in Knightwood Crescent. The property is not listed, nor is it within a conservation area, and there are no other historic assets in the vicinity. The site is located within flood zone 1 as defined by the Environment Agency. The planning history relevant to this application is:20/02117/HOU - Erection of part single, part two storey side extension. Erection of single storey rear extension. Erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with installation of 2no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Erection of rear detached outbuilding and conversion of existing garage to store room - refused November 202019 neighbouring properties were notified of the application and four objections were received following the consultation period. The issues raised in the responses are:Access or traffic problemsCar park issuesExcessive height or bulk of buildingsInappropriate design/layoutUnacceptable or incompatible useThe key areas of assessment are:The design of the proposed development;The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; andThe impact upon highway safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed side extension will be set-in from the side boundary with no. 41 Somerset Close, and so maintain an appearance of separation from the neighbour. Its height and size are in keeping with the original property and it will have the appearance of a traditional domestic extension. Within the rear roofslope, the proposed dormer would be set in from the ridge and eaves, as well as the sides so that it appears as a subordinate feature within the rear elevation. The single storey rear extension will be of an appropriate size and scale in relation to the property and will also have the appearance of a typical domestic extension. The outbuilding is also of an appropriate scale and appearance. Cumulatively, it is considered that the proposed additions would not unduly dominate the original property and so there would be no adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the area.Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The outbuilding would be located at the rear of the property in close proximity to boundaries with adjoining properties in Somerset Close as well as Knightwood Crescent. Given the size of the outbuilding as well as the size of the neighbouring gardens, it is not considered that the structure would unduly dominate these garden areas to the detriment of the occupants. It is recommended that permitted development rights are removed to prevent windows being installed within the side and rear elevations to prevent any overlooking of these gardens. The side extension would be located within close proximity to a similar addition at no. 41 Somerset Close and there are no windows within the side elevation of that neighbour that would be adversely affected by the proposal. The rear extension would be adjacent to the boundary with no. 35 Somerset Close, but is height and depth are such that an acceptable relationship with this neighbour would be maintained.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate an off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would comply with the Policy DM9 and DM10.In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a residential property on the south side of Moor Lane, which is a classified road that is maintained by the Council. There are examples of dropped kerbs at neighbouring properties that provide off-street parking space within the property curtilage. There are no street trees or grass verges that would be affected by the proposal.The proposed parking space will have dimensions of 5.1m x 5.8m, which is of adequate space, and will be positioned at a right angle to the highway. It is considered that this would be an acceptable size and accessible from the highway. The proposed development would therefore accord with policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy 2012 and the RBK Crossover Policy 2020.
Site Plan must show red outline

Please confirm description ''Raising roof height, erection of front and rear dormer roof extension and installation of 2 nos side rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Fenestration alteration and internal alteration.''

Please provide existing and proposed roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.Note: We require drawing of existing and proposed roof plans even there is no changes.
Please confirm that the proposed works are internal works and not external.If they are external works, you would be required to also submit a Section 73 application to vary the conditions.

Please confirm description of proposed works "Section 19 application to vary Condition 2 (Approved Plans) and Condition 3 (Additional Detailed Drawings) of Listed Building Consent ref: 14/13250/LBC (Alterations, reconfiguration, change of use of Telephone Exchange to offices (B1)/ residential cycle storage (partitions added) including demolition of outbuildings/boundary walls to east courtyard, west light-well walls, internal partitions/modifications to external stairs, fenestration, creation of new/restored openings, re-roofing of front range, installation of lift.) to provide minor internal changes "
